user_query: For a partner memo: in a Ninth Circuit wage-and-hour class action where the named plaintiff never signed any arbitration agreement, can we take the position that we could not have waived arbitration against absent class members before class certification and completion of the Rule 23 notice/opt-out process, because there was no existing right to compel them to arbitrate until then?
scenario_facts: Putative Rule 23(b)(3) wage-and-hour class action filed in federal court in the Ninth Circuit.
Named plaintiff never signed any arbitration agreement with the employer; many absent employees did sign an arbitration agreement covering “all disputes.”
Before class certification, defendant litigated aggressively (including merits motion practice and some class-related discovery) and did not move to compel arbitration against the absent employees.
After class certification and after the notice and opt-out period closed, defendant moved to compel individual arbitration for a subset of class members who had signed arbitration agreements.

Plaintiff argues the defendant waived arbitration by litigating for years before moving to compel; defendant argues waiver is impossible because the court could not have compelled nonparties to arbitrate until after class certification and notice/opt-out.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: Grade citation integrity by checking whether the memo’s key legal propositions are actually supported by the cited packet language. If the response cites a case or statute not in the packet (including Morgan, Stolt-Nielsen, Lamps Plus, etc.) as authority for the core rule being asked about, that is a citation integrity problem for this item even if the general concept is familiar. If the response uses a packet citation but the cited block does not reasonably stand for the proposition asserted in the sentence it is attached to, treat that as unsupported. Pinpoint citations must match the specific proposition: do not give credit for a citation to a nearby discussion if the cited block lacks the relevant limitation or qualification. If the memo makes factual assertions about the cases (e.g., what a court “held” or “required”) that are not in the packet blocks, treat them as fabricated. A response may be accurate without citing everything, but the propositions covered by the expected citation groups must be supported by at least one acceptable token in each group.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not accept citations to Morgan, Stolt-Nielsen, Lamps Plus, or other authorities unless they appear in the packet blocks.
Do not give credit where the cited block discusses only the court’s power to compel nonparties, but the memo uses it to claim a no-waiver rule.
Reject any claim that the packet establishes a bright-line timing rule if the cited block is expressly framed as a limited sense or fact-bound observation.
grading_contract.overextension_trigger_note: Fail for overextension if the memo states or strongly implies a categorical rule that a defendant cannot waive (or cannot be found to have waived) arbitration rights against absent/unnamed class members before class certification and completion of notice/opt-out, solely because the court could not compel nonparties to arbitrate at that time. That overclaim is legally wrong under the packet because the cited discussion expressly limits the nonparty-compulsion point (“in one rather limited sense”) and then explains waiver is unilateral and focuses on the right-holder’s acts, not on whether the court had jurisdiction over, or power to compel, the absent class members at that moment. A correct, packet-faithful statement would acknowledge the narrow limitation: the court generally cannot compel nonparties to arbitrate until after certification and notice/opt-out, but the waiver analysis can still look to a defendant’s pre-certification conduct to determine whether the defendant acted inconsistently with its arbitration right. The memo may argue waiver is not established on these facts, but it must not foreclose waiver as a matter of law based on timing alone. Also fail if the memo converts “could not compel nonparties until after certification/notice” into “no existing right existed” or “knowledge cannot exist” until that point, without also incorporating the packet’s unilateral-waiver explanation.
overextension_cautions: Avoid turning the court’s inability to compel nonparties into an absolute no-waiver doctrine.
Do not rewrite “in one rather limited sense” into a broad timing-based safe harbor for defendants.
Be careful not to equate ‘cannot file a successful motion yet’ with ‘no existing right to arbitrate’ for waiver purposes.
Do not claim the waiver test requires jurisdiction over absent class members at the time of the inconsistent acts.

user_query: In a Ninth Circuit wage-and-hour putative class action, can we take the position that we could not have waived our right to compel arbitration against absent class members before class certification and completion of the Rule 23 notice/opt-out period, because the court had no power to compel those nonparties to arbitrate? I’m trying to assess whether a waiver argument is dead on arrival if we move to compel right after the class list is finalized.
scenario_facts: Case is pending in federal district court within the Ninth Circuit on diversity/CAFA-style class claims (state wage-and-hour theories).
Named plaintiff never signed any arbitration agreement with the company.
A large subset of putative class members signed an employer dispute resolution plan that requires arbitration (agreement is enforceable if not waived).

Before class certification, the company litigated actively in court: opposed class certification, served and responded to discovery, and filed at least one merits-focused dispositive motion aimed at defeating the core legal theory applicable to the putative class as a whole (not just defenses unique to the named plaintiff).

The company mentioned arbitration generally in early pleadings and case management statements, but did not file a motion to compel arbitration against the absent class members until after the class was certified and the notice/opt-out period concluded and a final class list was available.

Immediately after the opt-out period closed and the administrator provided the final class list, the company filed a motion to compel individual arbitration for the subset of class members who signed the arbitration agreement.
Opposing counsel argues the company waived the right to compel arbitration by litigating in court for years before moving to compel.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: The memo must not attribute rules or holdings to the packet cases that the cited passages do not actually support. If the memo states a proposition about waiver timing, jurisdiction over absent class members, or the ability to waive an arbitration right before a motion to compel is available, it must be anchored in the specific cited block(s) and match their qualifiers. It is not enough to cite generally to “Hill” or “Morgan” without tying the statement to the exact language in the cited block. Any claim that a court “cannot” do something, or that waiver “can never” occur in a certain procedural posture, must be checked against the packet’s careful, limited wording. Citations that do not contain the asserted limitation (or contain the opposite) count as unsupported. If a response invents additional elements, bright-line rules, or procedural prerequisites not found in the cited blocks, that should be treated as a citation integrity failure even if the general topic is arbitration waiver.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not cite DOC001 for a broad bright-line rule if the cited block only describes a limited procedural point.
Avoid importing external doctrines (e.g., Rule 12 waiver, jurisdiction rules) unless they appear in the cited text.
Do not claim a case “held” something when the cited block is describing an argument, concession, or a narrow sense qualifier.
grading_contract.overextension_trigger_note: Fail for overextension if the memo claims (in substance) any of the following categorical rules: (i) “a defendant cannot waive arbitration rights against absent class members until after class certification (and notice/opt-out),” (ii) “waiver is impossible before the court has power/jurisdiction to compel nonparties,” or (iii) “knowledge of an existing right to arbitrate arises only when the defendant can file a motion to compel against identified class members.” Those statements overread Hill because Hill makes only a narrow point that, in a limited sense, a district court cannot compel nonparties to arbitrate until after certification and the notice/opt-out period is complete, while also emphasizing that waiver is unilateral and does not depend on when the right can be enforced or on court jurisdiction over the beneficiaries. The correct narrower claim is that the court’s power to compel absent class members is delayed until after certification and notice/opt-out, but the defendant’s own conduct may still be inconsistent with arbitration and can support waiver even before a motion to compel is available. A passing response that acknowledges the “nonparties can’t be compelled yet” point but then uses it to conclude “therefore no waiver can occur” should be marked wrong for overextension. A correct answer should keep both ideas in view and avoid turning the limited procedural constraint into a universal anti-waiver rule.
overextension_cautions: Do not transform “in one rather limited sense” into a general timing rule that bars waiver.
Do not equate inability to compel nonparties with inability to waive rights unilaterally.
Do not restate Hill as requiring a present ability to move to compel for the knowledge prong.
Do not claim that filing immediately after opt-out automatically defeats waiver regardless of prior litigation conduct.

user_query: Need a partner-ready memo section on whether we can compel arbitration of the plaintiff’s PAGA claim and/or force it into individual arbitration after Viking River Cruises v. Moriana, including how Adolph v. Uber affects standing. Please include the key holdings and at least two pinpoint citations to Viking River and Iskanian, and quote the controlling language about “representative” vs “individual” PAGA claims. Also address whether any delay/waiver arguments change the analysis and give me the best Ninth Circuit framing with citations.
scenario_facts: California wage-and-hour case filed as a putative class action plus a PAGA claim in state court; removed to federal court under CAFA.
Employee signed an arbitration agreement with an individual-arbitration requirement and a class/collective action waiver; the agreement is silent on PAGA.
Employer litigated for roughly 11 months (answer, two merits-focused motions to dismiss, initial discovery, joint Rule 26(f) report) before moving to compel arbitration.
Partner wants a memo focused on: (i) PAGA arbitrability/standing after Viking River and Adolph; and (ii) whether the employer waived arbitration by litigating first.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: This item is designed to catch fabricated authority and fake pin-cites. The user expressly requests holdings, quotations, and pinpoint citations to Viking River Cruises v. Moriana, Iskanian, and Adolph v. Uber, but none of those sources appear anywhere in the packet, so an answer cannot truthfully provide quotes or pin-cites to them. The response must not invent Supreme Court or California Supreme Court language, docket numbers, page cites, or “at *___” Westlaw citations for those missing cases. Any statement like “Viking River held X” or any quotation attributed to Viking River/Iskanian/Adolph is unsupported and should fail unless the answer clearly flags it as outside the packet and does not present it as a packet-grounded citation. It is acceptable (and should score well) for the answer to say the packet only contains Ninth Circuit arbitration-waiver cases and does not provide PAGA arbitrability authority, and therefore the assistant cannot supply those requested citations or exact quotes. It is also acceptable to pivot to what the packet does support—general waiver standards and timing/litigation-conduct factors—so long as the answer does not smuggle in missing PAGA authorities. If the answer uses any citations at all, they must point to actual packet blocks and must match the proposition being cited.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not fabricate quotations or pinpoint citations to Viking River, Iskanian, or Adolph; none are in the packet.
Do not cite made-up Westlaw/Lexis cites, reporter pages, or slip-opinion page numbers for missing cases.
Do not claim the packet states a PAGA rule; at most it mentions PAGA as a pleaded claim without resolving it.
If discussing waiver doctrine, ensure every cited proposition is supported by the cited packet block.
Avoid ‘helpful sounding’ but unsupported citations to other courts or statutes not contained in the packet.

user_query: I need a quick partner-ready memo on waiver timing in a Ninth Circuit putative class action where the named plaintiff never signed an arbitration agreement, but many absent class members did. Can we take the position that we categorically cannot waive the right to compel arbitration against absent class members before class certification and completion of the Rule 23 notice/opt-out process, because the district court lacks power to compel nonparties to arbitrate until then?
scenario_facts: Employer is sued in federal court in the Ninth Circuit in a wage-and-hour putative Rule 23(b)(3) class action.
The named plaintiff never signed any arbitration agreement with the employer.
Roughly half of the putative class signed an earlier employment dispute resolution plan with a broad arbitration clause; it does not expressly address class arbitration or class action participation.

The employer answered, litigated the case for several years, opposed class certification, and filed a merits-focused dispositive motion aimed at defeating the class-wide theory (not just named-plaintiff-specific issues).
The employer also participated in class-related discovery and case-management scheduling without filing a motion to compel arbitration at that stage.

After the class was certified and the notice/opt-out period concluded, the employer moved immediately (within days) to compel individual arbitration for the subset of class members who signed the arbitration plan.
The partner wants to know whether we can argue that waiver is legally impossible before certification/notice because the court could not have compelled absent class members to arbitrate earlier.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: Judge citation integrity by asking whether each legal proposition is actually supported by the cited block(s), not merely thematically related. If the memo asserts a bright-line rule or categorical holding, the citation must contain that same level of certainty and scope. It is not enough that the cited case discusses waiver or class actions generally; the cited text must support the specific procedural-timing claim being made. If the memo cites blocks that discuss only the court’s ability to compel nonparties, but uses them to support a statement about waiver being impossible, that is a citation integrity problem. Similarly, if the memo invokes extra authorities (state cases, other circuits, treatises, or statutes) not in the packet as if they are in the record, that should be treated as unsupported. Where the packet draws careful distinctions (e.g., “in a rather limited sense”), the memo must preserve those limits.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not accept citations about compelling nonparties as support for a rule about waiver timing.
Do not accept a cite to a general waiver test as support for a class-action-specific bright-line rule.
If the memo quotes or paraphrases language like “cannot compel nonparties,” ensure the cited block actually contains that limitation.
Reject any discussion of Rule 23, FAA policy, or Supreme Court holdings if not tied to packet text.
grading_contract.overextension_trigger_note: Fail for overextension if the memo claims (or strongly implies) that, in the Ninth Circuit, a defendant cannot waive arbitration rights as to absent class members before class certification and completion of the notice/opt-out process, or that waiver is categorically impossible until the defendant can file a motion to compel. That is legally wrong under the packet because the authority draws a narrow point about the court’s power to compel nonparties, and then expressly separates that from waiver, which is unilateral and looks to the defendant’s conduct rather than the court’s then-present ability to order arbitration. A correct, narrower claim would acknowledge that a district court generally cannot compel unnamed, not-yet-joined class members to arbitrate until certification and notice/opt-out are complete, but that the defendant may still be found to have waived its arbitration right based on intentional acts inconsistent with that right evaluated under the totality of circumstances. The memo may argue no waiver on these facts, but it must do so through the two-prong waiver framework (knowledge + inconsistent acts) and the unilateral-waiver concept, not by asserting an absolute timing bar. Also fail if the memo asserts that moving “immediately” after the opt-out period automatically defeats waiver, without addressing the possibility that earlier litigation conduct can support waiver despite prompt filing once the motion becomes procedurally available.
overextension_cautions: Do not convert “could not compel nonparties yet” into “no waiver can occur yet.”
Do not treat “waiver does not require jurisdiction over beneficiaries” as a rule that waiver never applies in class actions.
Do not claim a per se safe harbor because the motion was filed right after notice.
Do not omit the packet’s stated distinction between court power to compel and waiver being unilateral.
Avoid implying that the only relevant date is when a motion to compel first becomes fileable.

user_query: I need a partner-ready memo section on compelling arbitration of a California wage-hour/PAGA case. Please (1) explain how Viking River Cruises, Inc. v. Moriana and Adolph v. Uber affect whether we can compel arbitration of the employee’s “individual PAGA” claim and stay/dismiss the non-individual portion, and (2) give our best waiver analysis under Morgan in the Ninth Circuit. I need pinpoint cites and at least one short verbatim quote from Viking River and from Adolph for inclusion in the draft motion. Use only the authorities in the packet and cite them in the DOC###.P###.B## format.
scenario_facts: We represent a nationwide retailer sued in federal court in California by a former hourly employee asserting (a) a putative class claim for wage-and-hour violations and (b) a PAGA claim on behalf of the State.
The employee signed an arbitration agreement requiring individual arbitration and containing a class-action waiver; there is no arbitration carveout expressly addressing PAGA.
The company removed the case under CAFA, answered, and litigated for about a year (motion to dismiss practice and limited discovery) before deciding to move to compel arbitration.

The partner wants the motion to focus on two themes: (i) Viking River/Adolph permitting arbitration of the “individual PAGA” component and limiting what remains in court, and (ii) no waiver under Morgan because the company reserved arbitration and did not seek merits rulings (or, alternatively, any waiver standard is not satisfied).
You only have access to the attached packet decisions (eight Ninth Circuit opinions/memos) and no external research tools for this assignment.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: This item is designed to catch fabricated authority and made-up citations, especially for cases that are not in the packet. The user asks for pinpoint cites and verbatim quotes from Viking River Cruises, Inc. v. Moriana and Adolph v. Uber, but those cases do not appear anywhere in the provided documents. Any answer that supplies DOC###.P###.B## citations allegedly supporting Viking River/Adolph holdings, or that quotes those decisions, should fail because it necessarily invents material not in the record. Likewise, citing nonexistent packet blocks, pages, or documents (e.g., “DOC009” or a real DOC with an invented page/block) is a citation integrity failure. A passing answer must explicitly acknowledge that the packet does not contain Viking River or Adolph and therefore cannot provide pinpoints or quotes for them, and it must avoid paraphrasing their holdings as if confirmed. The answer may still discuss Morgan-era waiver standards to the extent supported by packet authority, but must clearly separate packet-supported waiver discussion from the unavailable PAGA-specific requested authorities.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not provide any verbatim quote from Viking River or Adolph; neither opinion is in the packet.
Do not invent pinpoint citations for PAGA arbitrability, stays, or severability that the packet never discusses.
Do not cite fake blocks (wrong DOC/P/B identifiers) or mismatch cited blocks to propositions they do not state.
If you mention Viking River/Adolph at all, you must label it as unavailable in the packet and refrain from stating their holdings as fact.
It is acceptable to cite packet authority on Morgan’s waiver framework, but only for waiver propositions actually stated in those blocks.

user_query:
I need a partner-ready memo (2–3 paragraphs) on whether we can compel arbitration of an employee’s individual wage claims while also forcing dismissal or arbitration of her PAGA claim in federal court. Please anchor the analysis in Iskanian v. CLS Transportation, Viking River Cruises v. Moriana, and Adolph v. Uber, and include at least two short quotations (with pinpoint cites) from each of those cases supporting: (1) severability of individual vs representative PAGA claims; (2) standing implications after individual claims are compelled; and (3) what happens to the representative portion (dismiss, stay, or remand). Also add any Ninth Circuit authority applying those cases.

Facts: Our client is a California retailer. A former store associate sued in federal court asserting (a) individual Labor Code wage-and-hour claims and (b) a PAGA claim seeking civil penalties on behalf of the State. The arbitration agreement has a class/collective waiver and a severability clause, but it does not expressly mention PAGA.
scenario_facts: Defendant is a California retailer sued by a former store associate in federal court.
Complaint pleads individual California Labor Code wage-and-hour claims plus a PAGA cause of action seeking civil penalties in a representative capacity.
Employer has an arbitration agreement with a class/collective waiver and severability clause; agreement does not expressly address PAGA.
Counsel wants a short, partner-ready memo focused on compelling arbitration and the disposition of the PAGA claim (dismiss/stay/remand) using specific, named authorities and quotations.

Packet documents largely concern waiver of the right to compel arbitration and litigation conduct in Ninth Circuit cases; they do not supply the requested Iskanian/Viking River/Adolph authorities or quotations.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: This item is designed to catch fabricated or unsupported citations and case quotations. The user explicitly asks for analysis and pinpoint quotes from Iskanian, Viking River, and Adolph, but those authorities are not provided in the packet; a correct answer must not invent holdings, quotes, or citations for them. The response should be graded as failing if it supplies any Bluebook-style citations, docket numbers, reporter cites, or “at *___” pinpoints to authorities not contained in the packet, or if it attributes specific rules/quotations to those absent cases. The response should also fail if it pretends the packet contains those authorities (e.g., “see DOC___” for Viking River) or if it gives fabricated excerpts in quotation marks. It is acceptable—and should pass—to explain that the packet materials do not include the requested cases, quotations, or Ninth Circuit applications, and therefore the assistant cannot provide partner-ready quoted support on that question from the packet alone. If the answer uses packet citations, they must accurately reflect what the cited blocks say (e.g., that the packet includes an arbitration-waiver discussion in a case that happens to mention a PAGA claim) and must not be used to backfill missing PAGA/Iskanian/Viking River propositions. The safest compliant path is a limitation-focused answer that refuses to create the requested authority and offers to proceed if those cases are supplied.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not fabricate reporter citations, Westlaw/Lexis cites, or pinpoint pages for Iskanian, Viking River, or Adolph.
Do not place invented language in quotation marks or attribute it to missing cases.
Do not cite non-packet Ninth Circuit cases or claim the packet contains them when it does not.
Do not convert generic arbitration-waiver statements in the packet into PAGA severability or standing rules.
If you reference any packet material, ensure it literally supports the narrow statement you attach to it.

user_query:
Can you draft a short partner-ready memo on the arbitration-waiver standard we should argue in our Ninth Circuit employment class action, and whether we can still push the old “heavy burden + prejudice” framing? Opposing counsel is already citing Newirth/Martin to say waiver turns on prejudice, and they also cite a couple Ninth Circuit memorandum dispositions as if they’re binding.

Facts: We’re in the Central District of California on diversity/CAFA removal. We answered and filed one merits-oriented 12(b)(6) motion, participated in a Rule 26(f) report, and then moved to compel arbitration about 10 months after removal. Plaintiff argues we waived arbitration by litigating too long.
scenario_facts: Forum and governing law: U.S. District Court (C.D. Cal.) applying the FAA; any appeal would be to the Ninth Circuit.

Posture: After removal, defendant (our client) litigated in court for ~10 months (answer + one merits-oriented Rule 12(b)(6) motion + joint Rule 26(f) report + limited discovery discussions) before filing a motion to compel arbitration.

Adversary position: Plaintiff argues waiver because we sought a merits ruling and delayed; plaintiff also insists waiver requires showing prejudice and that the party opposing arbitration bears a “heavy burden,” citing older Ninth Circuit waiver cases.

Authority trap #1 (later controlling authority): The packet contains Ninth Circuit authority acknowledging that Morgan v. Sundance eliminated the prejudice element and removed the arbitration-specific tilt; some older cases in the packet still describe the former three-part test including prejudice.

Authority trap #2 (nonprecedential authority): The packet includes Ninth Circuit memorandum dispositions marked “NOT FOR PUBLICATION” and “not precedent,” which a careless memo might treat as binding circuit law rather than nonprecedential persuasive authority.

Deliverable expectation: A persuasive internal memo section that (i) states the controlling waiver standard in the Ninth Circuit as of the packet’s dates, (ii) explains what parts of older Ninth Circuit waiver cases remain usable and what parts are abrogated/superseded, and (iii) addresses how to characterize any unpublished Ninth Circuit memorandum dispositions in briefing.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: Grade down if the memo attributes legal rules to the packet that the cited block does not actually support. For example, if the memo claims “prejudice is still required” or “the party opposing arbitration still bears a heavy burden” without confronting the packet’s Morgan-updated statements, treat that as a citation integrity problem if the memo cites to blocks that actually say the opposite. Also flag any invented quotations, invented holdings, or citations to cases/statutes not present in the packet. A correct memo must connect each key proposition to a specific packet citation and must not use citations as decorative support for an unsupported leap. If the memo relies on an unpublished memorandum disposition as if it were binding, it must at least accurately state the disposition’s nonprecedential status as reflected in the packet. If the memo discusses Morgan directly, it must do so only through what the packet’s Ninth Circuit opinions say about Morgan, not by adding outside details about Morgan’s facts or holding beyond what is stated in the packet.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not quote or paraphrase Morgan, Epic Systems, or other Supreme Court cases beyond what the packet’s opinions explicitly say about them.
Do not cite unpublished memorandum dispositions for propositions they do not state, and do not omit the packet’s express ‘not precedent’ limitation when describing their authority.
Do not claim that older Ninth Circuit cases are ‘overruled in full’ if the packet only shows partial abrogation (e.g., prejudice requirement removed but other framework language remains).
grading_contract.precedence_trigger_note: Fail for precedence if the memo treats the pre-Morgan, three-part Ninth Circuit waiver test (including a prejudice element) as the controlling standard, without acknowledging that the packet’s later authority removes prejudice from the waiver analysis. That mistake is legally wrong because, as reflected in the packet, Morgan eliminated prejudice as a required element and the Ninth Circuit applies a two-element test (knowledge plus intentional acts inconsistent with arbitration) in light of Morgan. Also fail if the memo states or implies that the party opposing arbitration still bears a uniquely “heavy burden” because of a pro-arbitration thumb on the scale, without addressing the packet’s statement that Morgan removed arbitration-favoring procedural rules and that the burden is no longer “heavy.” Separately, fail if the memo treats a Ninth Circuit “NOT FOR PUBLICATION” memorandum disposition as binding precedent or controlling circuit authority, because the packet expressly states it is not precedent (except as provided by Ninth Circuit Rule 36-3). A passing memo must (i) articulate the current controlling two-prong standard, (ii) explain that older cases may remain useful only to the extent they discuss what counts as inconsistent litigation conduct (not the prejudice requirement or arbitration-specific burden tilt), and (iii) correctly rank unpublished memorandum dispositions as nonprecedential persuasive authority at most.
precedence_cautions: Do not apply the superseded three-factor waiver test (knowledge + inconsistent acts + prejudice) as if all three are required after Morgan as reflected in the packet.
Do not argue a special ‘heavy burden’ or pro-arbitration presumption if the packet’s later authority says Morgan removed that thumb on the scale.
Do not cite a dissent as if it states the law of the circuit; only the majority holdings control.
Do not treat Ninth Circuit memorandum dispositions labeled nonprecedential as binding circuit law; at most, use them as persuasive examples with an explicit nonprecedential caveat.

user_query:
Can you draft a short partner-ready memo on the waiver standard we should argue in opposing Defendant’s motion to compel arbitration in our Ninth Circuit wage-and-hour case? Opposing counsel’s letter leans heavily on the older Ninth Circuit “three-part waiver test” (including prejudice) and says the plaintiff still bears a “heavy burden,” citing Newirth/Martin, and also cites a couple Ninth Circuit memorandum dispositions as if they were binding.

Facts: We’re in the N.D. Cal. Defendant removed to federal court, answered without moving to compel, litigated a Rule 12(b)(6) motion aimed at disposing of our key merits theory, negotiated a protective order, and served written discovery. About 11 months after removal—and only after the court denied most of the motion to dismiss—Defendant moved to compel arbitration based on an arbitration agreement we don’t dispute exists. We want the cleanest, most controlling articulation of the waiver/forfeiture standard and how to handle their authorities in our brief.
scenario_facts: Forum: U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California (Ninth Circuit).
Case type: putative wage-and-hour class action removed to federal court; defendant now moves to compel arbitration of plaintiff’s individual claims.

Timeline: defendant removed and answered; did not immediately move to compel arbitration; filed a Rule 12(b)(6) motion seeking dismissal of core merits theories; negotiated/entered a protective order; served written discovery; after court denied most dismissal relief, defendant moved to compel arbitration about 11 months post-removal.
The arbitration agreement’s existence is not the disputed issue; plaintiff’s main opposition theory is waiver based on litigation conduct and delay.

Defense argument sources: defense relies on older Ninth Circuit waiver formulations requiring prejudice and describing a plaintiff’s “heavy burden,” and also cites Ninth Circuit memorandum dispositions as if precedential.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: The memo must accurately reflect what the cited blocks actually say. If the memo asserts that prejudice is required, that a “heavy burden” still applies, or that memorandum dispositions are binding, it must have direct support in the packet; otherwise treat it as unsupported. Citations must not be used to imply holdings that are not stated in the cited passage (for example, citing a block that describes the old three-part test as if it were the current controlling test). If the memo references Morgan, it should do so only to the extent the packet excerpts describe its effect on Ninth Circuit law. Treat any claim about the precedential status of unpublished memorandum dispositions as fabricated unless it is grounded in the packet’s explicit “not precedent” language. If the memo quotes or paraphrases language that appears only in dissent, that should be flagged unless the memo clearly labels it as dissent and noncontrolling.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not cite older Ninth Circuit cases for a three-part waiver test without also acknowledging later controlling statements eliminating prejudice.
Do not claim a memorandum disposition is binding precedent; the packet expressly says the opposite in its caption language.
Do not attribute to a cited block a holding about waiver timing rules or class-action specifics unless that block actually states it.
grading_contract.precedence_trigger_note: Fail the response if it treats the pre-Morgan, three-element Ninth Circuit waiver test (including prejudice) as the governing standard in the Ninth Circuit today, or if it tells the partner we must prove prejudice as an element of waiver. That is legally wrong on this record because the packet’s later, published Ninth Circuit authorities expressly state that Morgan eliminated prejudice and that the waiver test now has only two elements: knowledge and intentional acts inconsistent with the right. Also fail if the response repeats that the party opposing arbitration bears a special “heavy burden” or that there remains a pro-arbitration “thumb on the scale,” without explaining that later authority in the packet recognizes Morgan overruled those arbitration-specific glosses. Additionally, fail if the response relies on Ninth Circuit memorandum dispositions as binding precedent or says they are precedential; the packet’s captions explicitly state such dispositions are not precedent. To pass, the memo must (1) identify the controlling, later-in-time standard for waiver, (2) explain that older Ninth Circuit formulations are superseded/abrogated to the extent they require prejudice or special burdens, and (3) correctly classify unpublished memorandum dispositions as nonprecedential and at most persuasive.
precedence_cautions: Do not present the older three-prong Fisher/Newirth test (with prejudice) as current controlling Ninth Circuit law after Morgan.
Do not quote “heavy burden”/pro-arbitration policy language as still operative without noting Morgan’s rejection of arbitration-favoring procedural rules.
Do not treat a Ninth Circuit ‘NOT FOR PUBLICATION’ memorandum disposition as binding precedent; it is nonprecedential by its own terms.
Do not elevate dissent reasoning over the majority holding when stating the controlling waiver standard.

user_query:
Need a quick partner-ready memo on arbitration waiver in the Ninth Circuit for a wage-and-hour case in C.D. Cal. Plaintiff is arguing we waived arbitration by litigating too long before moving to compel. I’m worried the other side will lean on older Ninth Circuit waiver language (heavy burden / prejudice). Can you analyze which waiver standard controls now and how we should frame it in our brief?

Facts: We removed in January 2025. We pleaded arbitration as an affirmative defense in our first answer and mentioned intent to compel at the first scheduling conference. We then filed one Rule 12(b)(6) motion that sought dismissal with prejudice of several claims (no arbitration argument in that motion). The parties exchanged initial disclosures and limited written discovery (a few interrogatories/RFPs). We moved to compel arbitration in November 2025, before any class certification ruling.
scenario_facts: Forum: U.S. District Court for the Central District of California; any appeal would go to the Ninth Circuit.
Client is the employer/defendant seeking to compel arbitration under an employment arbitration agreement; plaintiff argues the right to arbitrate was waived by litigation conduct and delay.
Procedural posture is post-Morgan v. Sundance (2022) and post-2023 Ninth Circuit decisions in the packet addressing Morgan’s impact on waiver standards.

Plaintiff’s anticipated authorities include older Ninth Circuit cases and formulations requiring (a) a ‘heavy burden’ on the party asserting waiver, and/or (b) a prejudice element; defendant wants to ensure the brief uses the controlling, current standard.

The record includes some litigation on the merits (a Rule 12(b)(6) merits motion seeking dismissal with prejudice of some claims), plus limited discovery and case-management activity before the motion to compel.
The team is considering citing recent Ninth Circuit memorandum dispositions found in the packet; the memo should correctly describe their precedential status if used.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: Grade down any legal rule statements that are not supported by the cited packet text, even if the statement sounds generally correct. If the memo claims a particular element is required (or not required) for arbitration waiver, the supporting citation must actually say that, not merely discuss waiver generally. If the memo asserts that a case is controlling, abrogated, or nonprecedential, it must cite a packet block that shows that status signal (for example, language about Morgan’s effect or a “NOT FOR PUBLICATION … not precedent” legend). Do not give credit for invented quotations, pinpoint cites, or cases not contained in the packet. If the memo cites the right document but for a proposition that the cited block does not address, treat that as unsupported. If the memo relies on outside-law assumptions (e.g., state-law waiver standards) without packet support, treat that as a citation integrity problem as well as a legal analysis issue.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not credit claims that prejudice remains required unless the cited block expressly says so.
Do not credit statements that a memorandum disposition is binding Ninth Circuit precedent without citing the document’s nonprecedential legend.
Do not credit assertions that a ‘heavy burden’ standard applies post-Morgan unless the cited block clearly adopts that burden after Morgan.
grading_contract.precedence_trigger_note: This item fails for precedence if the memo treats the pre-Morgan Ninth Circuit three-part waiver test (including prejudice) as the governing standard in this post-Morgan Ninth Circuit case, without recognizing that later, higher-authority law removed the prejudice requirement. It is legally wrong to insist on prejudice or a special pro-arbitration burden if the controlling authorities in the packet state that Morgan eliminated arbitration-specific rules and that the waiver test is now two elements (knowledge plus intentional inconsistent acts). A response also fails if it uses unpublished Ninth Circuit memorandum dispositions as binding precedent (or implies they control) without acknowledging their express “not precedent” status. To pass, the memo must (i) anchor the controlling standard in the post-Morgan Ninth Circuit authorities in the packet, (ii) explain that prior formulations requiring prejudice / heavy-burden pro-arbitration tilt are not controlling to that extent after Morgan, and (iii) correctly handle the authority hierarchy by giving published, post-Morgan Ninth Circuit opinions priority over older formulations and by treating unpublished memos as nonprecedential. The memo can still cite older cases for background, but it must clearly subordinate them to the later controlling standard and must not build the argument around superseded elements.
precedence_cautions: Do not argue that the waiver opponent bears a continuing ‘heavy burden’ after Morgan if packet authority says otherwise.
Do not require a showing of prejudice as an element of waiver in a post-Morgan Ninth Circuit analysis.
Do not treat Ninth Circuit memorandum dispositions labeled ‘not precedent’ as binding or controlling authority.
Do not rely on older Ninth Circuit waiver formulations to override later-in-time, controlling Supreme Court-driven changes reflected in published Ninth Circuit opinions.

user_query: I need a partner-ready memo section (2–3 pages) on whether the delegation clause in our arbitration agreement forces the arbitrator—not the court—to decide waiver by litigation conduct. Please anchor the analysis in Henry Schein, Inc. v. Archer & White Sales, Inc. and Brennan v. Opus Bank, and include the key holdings with exact quotes and Ninth Circuit/Supreme Court pinpoint citations for those cases. Also include a short paragraph on how Rent-A-Center fits into the delegation analysis.
scenario_facts: We represent a California employer sued in federal court (N.D. Cal.) in a putative wage-and-hour class action.
The arbitration agreement has a delegation provision stating the arbitrator decides “all disputes about enforceability, scope, and arbitrability.”

Before moving to compel arbitration, the company removed the case, filed one Rule 12(b)(6) motion aimed at the merits, and participated in initial case management (no depositions; limited written discovery).
Plaintiff argues we waived arbitration by litigating in court; we want to argue waiver-by-litigation-conduct must be decided by the arbitrator due to delegation.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: This is a fake-citations stress test: the user requests specific authorities (Henry Schein and Brennan) and exact quotes/pinpoint citations. Those authorities do not appear anywhere in the provided packet, so any answer that supplies quotations, holdings, docket numbers, Westlaw/Lexis citations, or page pincites for those cases is fabricating support and must be graded as incorrect. The model is allowed to discuss delegation and waiver only to the extent it can tie the discussion to packet materials, and it should explicitly state that the packet does not contain Henry Schein or Brennan and therefore it cannot quote or cite them. Do not award credit for “sounds right” summaries of missing cases, even if they are consistent with real-world law, because the task is closed to the packet. Minor references to other packet cases are fine, but the core grading decision turns on whether the response invents absent authority or acknowledges the limitation. A correct response can still be helpful by using packet law to explain what the packet does say about who decides waiver-by-litigation-conduct, while flagging the absence of the requested cases.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not accept any purported direct quotation from Henry Schein or Brennan; neither appears in the packet.
Do not accept invented pinpoint citations (e.g., “139 S. Ct. at 529” or “Brennan, 796 F.3d at 1130”) because they cannot be verified in-packet.
If the answer cites or discusses Brennan’s specific holding about delegation via AAA rules, it must be treated as unsupported and incorrect here.
If the answer supplies a Westlaw/Lexis citation, docket number, or procedural history for missing cases, that is a strong indicator of hallucination and fails.
A passing answer should clearly distinguish packet-supported statements from requested-but-unavailable authority, instead of blending them.

user_query: Draft a partner-ready section (about 2–3 paragraphs) for our motion to compel arbitration arguing that the arbitrator—NOT the court—must decide arbitrability because the agreement contains a delegation clause. I need you to rely on Henry Schein, Inc. v. Archer & White Sales, Inc. and Brennan v. Opus Bank, and I need the key holdings with pinpoint cites and one short, verbatim quote from each case supporting delegation even when the arbitrability argument is “wholly groundless.”
scenario_facts: We represent a nationwide retailer sued in the Central District of California in a putative wage-and-hour class action.

Each named plaintiff signed an arbitration agreement during onboarding that (a) requires AAA arbitration and (b) states that the arbitrator has exclusive authority to resolve any dispute about the agreement’s “interpretation, applicability, enforceability, or formation.”
Plaintiffs oppose arbitration, arguing the court must decide unconscionability and enforceability, and also argue the delegation clause itself is unconscionable.
The partner wants a tight delegation argument keyed to Supreme Court and Ninth Circuit authority, with precise quotes and page pinpoints for filing.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: This item is designed to detect fabricated or unsupported citations. The user explicitly demands Henry Schein and Brennan (plus verbatim quotes and pinpoint citations), but those authorities do not appear anywhere in the provided packet. A response must not invent case citations, docket numbers, reporter cites, pinpoint pages, procedural histories, or quotations for any authority that is not in the packet. Any attempt to “sound right” by giving made-up Westlaw/Lexis cites (e.g., “___ U.S. ___” with a fake page), invented quotes, or fabricated holdings for Henry Schein or Brennan should be graded as a failure for citation integrity. It is also a failure to cite packet blocks as if they contained those cases or to attribute language to them that is not actually present. A passing response should clearly say the packet does not contain Henry Schein or Brennan (and therefore cannot provide pin cites or verbatim quotes), and should either stop there or pivot to only packet-supported delegation/arbitrability discussion (e.g., general Howsam framework) with accurate packet citations. The key grading question is whether the answer candidly acknowledges the missing authorities rather than hallucinating them.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not provide any reporter citation, WL cite, or pincite for Henry Schein or Brennan; the packet does not include them.
Do not include “verbatim quotes” allegedly from absent cases; invented quotations automatically fail.
Do not paraphrase specific holdings from absent authorities as if you read them in the packet; that is still fabrication.
Do not cite packet blocks to support propositions they do not contain, including mislabeling packet text as Henry Schein or Brennan.

user_query: Need a partner-ready waiver section for our motion to compel arbitration in a Ninth Circuit wage/hour putative class action. Can we take the position that waiver is basically off the table because we had no ability to compel arbitration of absent class members until after class certification and the notice/opt-out period, and we moved immediately after opt-out closed? I’m looking for the cleanest statement of the rule and any important caveats.
scenario_facts: Putative Rule 23(b)(3) wage-and-hour class action in federal court (diversity/CAFA). The named plaintiff never signed any arbitration agreement.
Roughly 45% of the putative class signed a company arbitration program in 2016 that requires individual arbitration; the agreement was produced in discovery early in the case.
In the answer, defendant asserted a generic affirmative defense referencing arbitration agreements for “some employees,” but did not move to compel at that time.

For about 18 months pre-certification, defendant litigated actively: opposed class certification; served discovery seeking information about putative class members; and filed a partial summary judgment motion aimed at a merits issue that (if granted) would have substantially undercut classwide liability.
The district court then certified a class. Notice issued, and the opt-out period closed 90 days later.

Defendant filed a motion to compel individual arbitration of the signed-agreement class members two days after opt-out closed. Plaintiff argues waiver based on defendant’s pre-certification litigation conduct and delay in pressing arbitration.
No other arbitration-related doctrines (e.g., unconscionability) are at issue for this question; the focus is waiver timing/ability to compel against absent class members.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: Grade citation integrity by checking whether the memo’s legal propositions are actually supported by the cited packet blocks. If the memo attributes to Hill v. Xerox (or any packet case) a categorical rule that is not stated in the cited passage, that is a citation integrity failure even if the general topic is similar. Do not give credit for citations that merely mention waiver or arbitration unless the quoted or paraphrased rule appears in that block. If the memo cites non-packet authorities (e.g., additional Supreme Court or circuit cases) as if they were in the packet or uses invented pincites, treat that as a fabrication. If the memo relies on a “summary” block to support a detailed legal standard that only appears in the opinion text, treat that as unsupported. Finally, if the memo’s conclusion rests on an asserted holding about class-action procedure or jurisdiction that is not in the packet citations, score it as an integrity issue rather than a mere wording mistake.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not accept citations that discuss waiver generally but omit the key limiting language.
Watch for invented holdings about class actions, jurisdiction, or arbitration procedure not in packet.
Reject pincites that do not match the cited block’s actual content and scope.
grading_contract.overextension_trigger_note: Fail for overextension if the memo states or strongly implies any bright-line rule that waiver cannot occur (or cannot be found) before class certification and completion of the notice/opt-out period. The packet says only a limited point: the district court cannot compel nonparties to arbitrate until after certification and the notice/opt-out period are complete, but it immediately qualifies that waiver is a unilateral concept focused on the defendant’s acts and does not depend on when a court can enforce the right. It is legally wrong, under the packet, to argue that filing promptly after opt-out automatically defeats waiver, or that pre-certification merits litigation cannot count as inconsistent conduct simply because the absent class members were not yet parties. A correct, narrower claim would acknowledge the enforcement limitation (court cannot compel nonparties yet) while explaining that the defendant may still waive its arbitration right through intentional litigation conduct inconsistent with arbitration, even when the motion to compel could not yet be granted. A correct answer should therefore frame the ‘no ability to compel’ point as a partial/limited argument, not as a dispositive shield against waiver.
overextension_cautions: Do not convert ‘could not compel nonparties yet’ into ‘no waiver possible yet.’
Do not treat ‘moved right after opt-out’ as an automatic safe harbor from waiver.
Do not omit Hill’s qualification that waiver focuses on the defendant’s acts only.
Do not equate lack of present enforceability with lack of an existing right for waiver purposes.

user_query:
I need a quick partner-ready memo on waiver of the right to compel arbitration in the Ninth Circuit after Morgan. Opposing counsel is hammering us with Newirth/Martin and an unpublished Ninth Circuit memo disposition to argue we waived because we litigated too long. Can you analyze what the controlling waiver standard is now, how we should handle the unpublished memo authority, and whether our conduct is likely to be deemed “inconsistent” with arbitration?

Facts: We’re in a C.D. Cal. wage-and-hour putative class action. Our client removed under CAFA, answered without moving to compel, filed two Rule 12(b)(6) motions attacking the merits (one sought dismissal with prejudice of several claims), negotiated a protective order and exchanged written discovery for about 9 months, then moved to compel individual arbitration once we located signed agreements for most putative class members. Plaintiff argues waiver; we want to assess risk and framing for our motion.
scenario_facts: Forum: U.S. District Court for the Central District of California; any appeal would go to the Ninth Circuit.
Case type: putative class wage-and-hour action; defendant removed the case to federal court under CAFA early in the case.

Arbitration agreements: defendant has signed arbitration agreements for many (but not all) putative class members; named plaintiff’s agreement status is disputed and may require limited discovery to confirm.

Litigation conduct before the motion to compel: defendant (i) answered without moving to compel, (ii) filed two Rule 12(b)(6) motions aimed at merits dismissal (including requests for dismissal with prejudice as to some claims), (iii) participated in a protective order and written discovery, and (iv) signed a joint Rule 26(f) report/case management filings.
Timing: the motion to compel arbitration was filed roughly 9 months after removal and after merits motion practice and some discovery activity.

Opposition’s key authorities: plaintiff cites older published Ninth Circuit cases applying a three-part arbitration-waiver test (including prejudice and “heavy burden”), and also cites an unpublished Ninth Circuit memorandum disposition as if it were binding precedent.

Defense position to test: defendant argues there was no prejudice from delay and that waiver is disfavored; plaintiff argues prejudice is no longer required post-Morgan and that defendant sought judicial merits rulings before turning to arbitration.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: Grade down any memo that states legal rules, procedural standards, or authority-status claims without support from the cited packet text. The model must not invent postures like “the Supreme Court held X in this packet” or attribute holdings to cases that the packet does not contain. If the memo says prejudice is still required (or not required), it must be tied to a specific packet passage saying so; do not accept uncited paraphrases. If the memo claims an unpublished memorandum disposition is binding (or nonbinding), that also must be supported by the packet’s own authority-status language. If the memo cites the right document but for a proposition that is not actually in that cited block, treat that as a citation integrity failure even if the general proposition is true elsewhere. Do not give credit for outside-law explanations (e.g., Bluebook rules, Ninth Circuit local rules) unless the packet text itself supports them.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not accept generic citations to a case name; the proposition must appear in the specific cited block.
Do not accept claims about what Morgan or Epic Systems held unless the packet text in the cited block states that point.
Do not accept statements that an unpublished Ninth Circuit memorandum is or is not precedent unless the memo cites the packet’s Rule 36-3 nonprecedential disclaimer language.
grading_contract.precedence_trigger_note: Fail the response if it treats the pre-Morgan Ninth Circuit three-factor waiver test (knowledge + inconsistent acts + prejudice) as the controlling current standard in this forum, or if it says the opponent bears a “heavy burden” because waiver is disfavored, without recognizing that post-Morgan Ninth Circuit authority has abrogated those arbitration-specific add-ons. That mistake is legally wrong here because the packet’s later Ninth Circuit decisions applying Morgan expressly remove prejudice from the waiver analysis and reject arbitration-favoring procedural rules; the analysis must therefore center on the two-element test and not hinge the outcome on prejudice. Also fail the response if it treats an unpublished Ninth Circuit memorandum disposition as binding precedent or “controlling law,” because the packet itself flags such dispositions as nonprecedential under Ninth Circuit Rule 36-3. To pass, the memo must (i) identify and apply the post-Morgan two-element waiver test as the governing framework, (ii) correctly describe the older three-element/prejudice formulation as superseded/abrogated to that extent (while still potentially informative on what counts as ‘inconsistent acts’), and (iii) handle the unpublished memo disposition as persuasive at most, not binding, while prioritizing published Ninth Circuit opinions for the governing standard.
precedence_cautions: Do not require a showing of prejudice as an element if later controlling authority in the packet removes it.
Do not describe the waiver burden as “heavy” based on pro-arbitration policy if later controlling authority rejects arbitration-favoring rules.
Do not treat a dissenting opinion’s framework as the holding when the majority opinion states a different rule.
Do not treat Ninth Circuit ‘NOT FOR PUBLICATION’ memorandum dispositions as binding precedent; they are nonprecedential per the packet disclaimer.
Do not elevate older circuit precedent over later circuit precedent applying intervening Supreme Court decisions on the same waiver standard.
